fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of a man, said to be Quentin Kennedy, watercolour on vellum, English school, 1659.
fields.physical_description: Portrait of a man, head and shoulders, to front and wearing armour and a white collar. Features in long strokes of bright red with a little shading in grey and blue and with black for the eyes with spots of white, on a pale creamy carnation ground; hair in loose sparse hatches of grey over the bare vellum; collar in white wash modelled in grey; armour washed and hatched in black and grey and with white for the lights; the studs in brown and metallic gold; background a solid dark brown to the left, pale brown to the right; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Frame: Nineteenth-century silver-gilt locket, the convex back roughly soldered to the straight sides, which hold the convex glass by its curved edges in a bezel; the hanger of broad flat wire bent into a trefoil loop and soldered to the top of the locket; engraved on the back in nineteenth-century lettering: Quentin Kennedy / younger son of / Hugh Kennedy of Bennan / born 1599/ married his cousin Madelina / daughter of Andrew Ross of Garstin / was many years / Dep.ty Gov.r of Jamestown Virginia / died 1670/ R. +P.
fields.title: A Man, said to be Quentin Kennedy
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum. London: The Stationery Office, 1997. Cat.195, p. 323. Full citation: "A Man, said to be Quentin Kennedy (b. 1599 d. 1670) 1659 Evans 55 Oval 52 x 43 mm Features in long strokes of bright red with a little shading in grey and blue and with black for the eyes with spots of white, on a pale creamy carnation ground; hair in loose sparse hatches of grey over the bare vellum; collar in white wash modelled in grey; armour washed and hatched in black and grey and with white for the lights; the studs in brown and metallic gold; background a solid dark brown to the left, pale brown to the right; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Condition: Faded, especially in the face; apparently an area of disturbed pigment below the date and a fragment of gold, possibly part of a former signature. Signed: Possibly formerly signed; dated in gold, lower centre left: 1659. Frame: Nineteenth-century silver-gilt locket, the convex back roughly soldered to the straight sides, which hold the convex glass by its curved edges in a bezel; the hanger of broad flat wire bent into a trefoil loop and soldered to the top of the locket; engraved on the back in nineteenth-century lettering: Quentin Kennedy / younger son of / Hugh Kennedy of Bennan / born 1599/ married his cousin Madelina / daughter of Andrew Ross of Garstin / was many years / Dep.ty Gov.r of Jamestown Virginia / died 1670/ R. +P. Provenance: According to a note by Long, bought by the Hon. F H A Wallop in Ireland; lent to the V&A 1927-49; given to Alan Evans, 1933, and by him bequeathed to the National Gallery 1974; placed on indeterminate loan at the V&A. (See Appendix 3.) Literature: Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 78 (Anon., English, mid-seventeenth century). The typed Museum label draft stuck into the Wallop Loan Book attributes this esoterically as 'possibly by the master of Simon Digby'. Digby was educated at Trinity College, Dublin, became Rector of Dunshaughlin, chaplain to the Earl of Ossory (1668), Bishop of Limerick (1678) and of Elphin (1691). Miniatures by him are at the Digby family home, Sherborne Castle, Dorsetshire, and the National Gallery of Ireland, etc.(1) An attribution to Digby himself was doubtless ruled out by the date of the miniature: 1659 being too early for him, the work must therefore have been by his master. The logic was not Long's, and Long wrote firmly above the label 'Owner's description'. The identification of the sitter was probably due to a member of the family similarly matching dates of portraits to the family tree. The Kennedys were the Earls of Cassillis in the Scottish peerage, important Presbyterians in the generations following the conversion - said to have been by Cranmer himself - of Gilbert Kennedy (1515-1558), 3rd Earl of Cassillis. The family had Irish and American ramifications typical of these dynamic west Scottish families. The inscription on the case specifying the sitter as the Deputy Governor of Jamestown probably resulted from a search of R Pitcairn, Historical and Genealogical Account of the Principal Families of the Name of Kennedy (Edinburgh, 1830) or of the Historical Account of the Noble Family of Kennedy, Marquis of Ailsa and Earl of Cassillis; with notices of the principal Cadets thereof (Edinburgh, 1849). 1 Long 1929. p. 125; Foskett 1972, vol. I, p. 245, vol. II. figs 227-8. The framing of the miniature seems intended to reinforce this Irish ecclesiastical association. The hanger is, uniquely and awkwardly, shaped as a shamrock, or lesser-clover; the shamrock, used by St Patrick to illustrate the doctrine of the Trinity, became the emblem of the Irish nation."
fields.credit: Alan Evans Bequest, given by the National Gallery
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> According to a note by Long, bought by the Hon. F H A Wallop in Ireland; lent to the V&A 1927-49; given to Alan Evans, 1933, and by him bequeathed to the National Gallery 1974; placed on indeterminate loan at the V&A.
